title: FirstFT: Fed moves step closer to tapering
text:
The Federal Reserve has moved one step closer to the day when it will start slowing its massive monetary support for the US economy, following a meeting of policymakers that highlighted both the promise and the perils of the American recovery.

At the end of a two-day meeting, the Federal Open Market Committee declared that it had made “progress” towards its goals of full employment and 2 per cent average inflation, even though it was not yet sufficient to merit any policy action right now.

The statement marked the first milestone in the US central bank's steady drive towards a decision on reducing its $120bn a month debt purchases, a move that could come later this year or early next year.

However, the central bank said any such “tapering” would require additional improvements in the economy and Jay Powell, Fed chair, said there was more “ground to cover” before it acts.

“We expect further progress, and we expect that if things go well then we will reach that goal. And when we reach it, and the committee is comfortable that we have reached it, then we'll taper at that point,” Powell said.

Four more stories in the news

1. China seeks to ease international investor fears Regulators in Beijing held a call with executives from global investors, Wall Street banks and Chinese financial groups last night, according to three people familiar with the matter, to ease concerns after tough new restrictions on private education companies sent shockwaves through markets. News of the call boosted Chinese shares today.

  • In related news: SoftBank is selling a large chunk of its stake in ride-hailing group Uber as the world's most aggressive technology investor wrestles with heavy losses from a big bet on China's Didi Chuxing.

2. US infrastructure deal advances after passing key vote US senators voted to advance a $1tn bipartisan infrastructure spending bill for investment on roads and bridges, the electric grid, railways and the country's broadband network. The 67 to 32 vote followed the agreement of a group of centrist senators and the White House. Read more on the details of the deal here.

3. Facebook warns of ‘significant' slowdown in revenue growth Facebook warned that the pace of its revenue growth would “decelerate significantly” in forthcoming quarters, sending its shares down in after-hours trading. The warning came after the social network posted bumper revenues and profits for the second quarter. Shares fell nearly 4 per cent in after-hours trading to around $360.

4. Morgan Stanley joins other Wall Street banks in lifting junior pay
Morgan Stanley staff were told yesterday that the pay for first-year investment bank analysts would rise to $100,000 a year with second-year analysts taking home $105,000, according to a person familiar with the matter. The increase brings Morgan Stanley in line with the likes of JPMorgan, Citigroup and Barclays in salaries for junior investment bankers.

Tokyo Olympics round-up

  • Reigning pole vault world champion Sam Kendricks has pulled out of the Games after testing positive for Covid-19 just a day before the athletics competition begins. Rival vaulter Germán Chiaraviglio from Argentina was also forced to withdraw after a positive test.

  • American Caeleb Dressel became the fastest swimmer ever at an Olympics. He won the men's 100m freestyle, the marquee swimming sprint, in an Olympic record time of 47.02 seconds.

  • China stormed to victory in the women's 4 x 200m freestyle relay, leading from start to finish to post a world record time of 7:40.33. The silver went to a US team anchored by Katie Ledecky, while bronze went to an Australian team led out by Ariarne Titmus. 

  • A late jump shot by Latvia's Karlis Lasmanis earned his country a gold medal in the first Olympic men's 3x3 basketball tournament. The US beat ROC in the women's final in the shorter form of basketball which is making its Olympics debut in Tokyo.

Add ‘Tokyo Olympics' to myFT for all our coverage from the Games, and don't miss our “alternative medals table”.

The day ahead

Robinhood shares begin trading Shares in the popular trading app begin trading on the Nasdaq today under the ticker symbol ‘HOOD'. Robinhood priced its shares at $38 apiece, the low end of its target range, giving the company a valuation of $31.7bn.

US economic growth Data from the US commerce department is expected to show US gross domestic product advanced 8.5 per cent on an annualised basis in the second quarter as a surge in vaccinations released pent up economic demand among consumers.

Earnings Amazon today becomes the latest technology company to release earnings. It will be the first set of results to be released by Amazon since founder Jeff Bezos stepped back from the day-to-day running of the online retailer and handed over to new chief executive Andy Jassy.

More earnings: Card issuer Mastercard and social network Pinterest also report second-quarter earnings today.

Biden to announce new Covid restrictions President Joe Biden will announce that millions of federal workers must show proof of a coronavirus vaccine or submit to regular testing and stringent social distancing, masking and travel restrictions. (AP)

Coronavirus digest

  • Google and Facebook have said they will require workers to be vaccinated against Covid-19 before they return to work at their US campuses.

  • Pfizer has raised its full-year revenue projections for its coronavirus vaccine by almost a third after the shot helped the drugmaker to almost double its sales in the second quarter.

  • The eurozone's GDP, out Friday, is expected to increase at its fastest rate in two decades, but there are fears governments could cut support too soon.

Sign up for our Coronavirus Business Update newsletter and get the latest on our blog.

What else we're reading

Three questions from the Nixon era for Joe Biden August marks the 50th anniversary of a momentous event: Richard Nixon, then the US president, summoned his advisers to Camp David. As Gillian Tett notes, the subject of discussion wasn't war or foreign policy. They were there to take the collective decision to sever the dollar's link with the gold standard.

Lebanon's year from hell A blast in Lebanon's port on August 4 2020 killed more than 200 people, injured thousands and caused some $4bn worth of damage. It should have been a nadir for Lebanon. Instead, it was the beginning of a further fall, a year-long plunge into economic chaos, writes Chloe Cornish, who lives a mile from where the blast took place.

Music labels split over Spotify royalty plan Towards the end of last year, Spotify began asking record companies to participate in “Discovery Mode”, through which Spotify prioritises an artist's songs on select music feeds in exchange for reduced royalties. Yet so far the reaction from the major labels has ranged from lip service to staunch opposition.

Make time for the people at the edge of your life The low-stakes conversations with people you see infrequently are commonly referred to as “weak ties”. They are the people on the periphery of your life. Missing out on these contacts can hinder career progress and creativity, and increase loneliness — problems that are especially pronounced among younger people in the Millennial and Gen Z groups, writes Elizabeth Uviebinene.
